visibility_factors: brief light freezing rain overnight (icing risk on untreated surfaces)
patchy freezing fog late evening/night with near-zero visibility at times

alert_summary.description: In effect Tuesday 2026-01-27 until 7:00 PM EST (includes Kent County). Impacts include slick roads/bridges and periods of very low visibility in snow/blowing snow.
Ice jam flooding risk along the Muskegon River (Newaygo County) through Tuesday 2026-01-27 7:00 PM EST.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford, MI on Wednesday (2026-01-28), temperatures remain well below freezing all day (low near -1°F, high near 14°F) so any moisture will freeze on contact. Total liquid is very light (~0.01"), but the precipitation type signal is light freezing rain overnight into early morning (around 12 AM–6 AM), which can create a thin glaze on untreated roads/sidewalks—an outsized impact risk for Michigan compared with light snow. Winds are modest (max ~14 mph) but wind chills are subzero, limiting melt and allowing slick spots to persist into the morning commute. Visibility is mostly acceptable during the day, but late evening/night freezing fog shows near-zero visibility potential, which is more of a travel hazard than a closure driver for the school day. Net: low snowfall concerns, but a non-trivial 'ice is the great equalizer' risk early Wednesday—more likely to produce delays/cautious operations than a widespread snow day unless icing is a bit heavier than forecast or untreated back roads remain slick.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Post-lake-effect/clipper cold snap with only light lingering precip: very cold air in place (high near 14°F, low around 0°F) and breezy W/WNW winds (10–15 mph), but little to no new snow accumulation during the school-day window.

Light freezing rain or patchy freezing drizzle occurring mainly overnight/early morning with minimal QPF (~0.01" liquid), leading to isolated slick spots on untreated roads/sidewalks but not a widespread ice storm.

Freezing fog late evening/night after a cold day (very high humidity, near-zero visibility pockets), which can create localized glaze on bridges and dips, but typically improves after sunrise if winds mix slightly.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in West Michigan commonly features subfreezing temperatures, lake-effect variability, and occasional advisory-level events. Districts in this region generally remain open unless there is (1) a true ice storm with notable glaze, (2) blizzard/near-whiteout conditions during the morning commute, or (3) dangerous wind chills (often near/below -15°F wind chill threshold).
unusual_factors: Primary hazard signal is ice-type precip ("light freezing rain") rather than snow accumulation; totals are small but impacts can be outsized if it coincides with the early bus/commute window.
Temperatures remain well below freezing all day (around 0°F to mid-teens), so any glaze that forms will not melt and can persist into the morning.
Visibility risk is localized: several hours show very low visibility (0–1 mi or even near 0), consistent with brief fog/freezing fog pockets rather than a broad snowstorm.

local_microclimates: US-131 corridor and nearby open/rural areas can see patchy blowing/drifting from prior snow (even with little new snow), especially where fields are exposed.
Low spots/river-adjacent areas can favor fog/freezing fog formation overnight, creating localized 'black ice' zones.
Lake-effect bands can shift quickly; however, the provided Wednesday forecast looks like the lake-effect focus diminishes compared with Tuesday’s advisory.
infrastructure_considerations: Michigan districts (including the Rockford area) are equipped for light-to-moderate snow and typically do not close for small accumulations alone.
Bridges/overpasses and untreated neighborhood roads are the biggest operational risk here because subfreezing temps all day prevent improvement without treatment.
If freezing rain occurs during ~5–8 AM, bus-route safety and intersection traction become the main closure lever, even with low precipitation totals.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford’s modest elevation changes won’t drive big snow totals, but can matter for cold-air pooling overnight (slick spots in valleys/low-lying roads) and for bridge icing on elevated roadways.

history.confidence_assessment: Overall snow-day risk for Wednesday 2026-01-28 looks LOW to LOW-MODERATE based on the forecast provided: essentially no accumulating snow (0 cm) and only ~0.01" liquid, with temps staying below freezing. The only realistic closure trigger in this setup is an early-morning glaze event (light freezing rain/freezing drizzle) or localized freezing fog causing widespread slickness—especially if it coincides with the bus/commute window and road treatment is limited. Wind chills appear cold (roughly -5°F to about -15°F at times), but generally not extreme enough by typical Michigan closure standards unless winds trend higher than forecast or temperatures drop further.

safety_recommendations: Treat Wednesday morning (6–8 AM) as a flash-freeze/black-ice commute: temperatures stay well below freezing while light freezing rain is indicated around 05:00–06:00, making untreated surfaces (especially bridges, overpasses, and subdivision streets) prone to glazing.

Prioritize bus route risk on secondary roads: hills, curves, and stop-heavy neighborhood segments may remain slick even if main corridors improve; consider holding/adjusting the most rural or hilly routes first if spot glazing is observed.

Have crews salt early: target 4:30–6:30 AM on known trouble spots (bridges/ramps, shaded stretches, school entrances, and parking lots/walkways) since very light precip can still produce a thin but high-impact glaze.

Expect reduced visibility in pockets even after precip ends: visibility is forecast around 3 miles from ~06:00–09:00 and freezing fog is possible late evening; run headlights and increase following distance.

Cold exposure planning: wind chills near -5 to -10°F around the commute window increase risk for students waiting at stops; shorten outdoor wait times and ensure supervision/warm-up options if delays occur.
Do not rely on 'no snow' to mean low risk: freezing rain is typically higher-impact than light snow for bus braking and student walking surfaces.

This is a strong regional signal that road/visibility conditions have been hazardous and could influence Wednesday morning (Jan 28) school decisions if conditions persist or refreeze overnight.

news.key_findings_summary: For Rockford, Michigan (Kent County) looking ahead to Wednesday, 2026-01-28: I did not find an official Rockford Public Schools closure/delay announcement specifically for Jan 28 in the district’s public news feed as of Tuesday, Jan 27. However, there are strong regional hazard signals from Tuesday’s conditions: FOX 17’s live blog reported multiple major West Michigan freeway crashes/closures (including a multi-vehicle pile-up on M-6 in the Kent-area) with MSP/MDOT updates citing icy roads and whiteout/low-visibility conditions. Community chatter (r/grandrapids) also referenced poor visibility on a Rockford-to-Byron Center commute. Neighboring-district-specific Jan 28 closure posts did not surface in the sources reviewed, but at least one nearby district (Sparta) has already issued weather closures earlier this month, which can be a weak “pattern” signal for how volatile conditions have been. Overall: official district signals for Jan 28 are not yet public, while road/travel risk signals in the region are elevated—suggesting a meaningful chance of delay/closure if conditions persist overnight or refreeze.

County arterials improving but some secondary bus-route segments may still be icy where freezing drizzle persists into early morning.

infrastructure.overall_clearing_assessment: For Rockford (Kent County) on Wed 2026-01-28: this looks less like a deep-snow event and more like a high-risk ice event. With temps near 0°F to single digits and periods of light freezing rain/freezing fog around the overnight-to-6 AM window, crews can treat, but refreeze is immediate and spotty. Expect state highways and primary arterials to be serviceable by first bell, but the 6:30 AM bus window is marginal—especially for rural/secondary routes, bridges, and shaded curves. If the freezing drizzle/low visibility verifies in the pre-dawn hours, a DELAY is more plausible than a full closure based on roads alone.

final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreement across experts: this is NOT a snow-accumulation event; the main school-morning hazard is ICE/black ice from light freezing rain/drizzle and potential freezing fog, with very cold temps preventing melt. Most agree a DELAY is more likely than a full closure.
2) Disagreement: wind chill severity. WeatherAPI keeps wind chill around ~-4 to -8°F (no closure trigger), while Weather.com shows ~-22 to -24°F during 5–8 AM (would strongly push closure). NWS hourly wind chill could not be confirmed in-session, so I cannot treat ≤ -20°F as verified.
3) Plow timing math: precip/icing risk extends to ~07:00; bus window ~06:30. That leaves ~0–0.5 hours from precip end to buses (too little buffer). Infrastructure expects state highways trending passable but not clear by 06:30; county roads improving closer to 08:30; local streets often not in good shape until ~10:00. This supports disruption but leans DELAY over full closure.
4) Any ice? Yes—this is the dominant risk factor, with high ice-formation risk from safety/infrastructure.
5) Neighboring districts: no confirmed Wed full-day closures found; however, Forest Hills has Wed afternoon activities canceled (mild signal of continued impacts). Lack of multiple confirmed district closures keeps probability from jumping.
6) Power outages: system-wide outages are low; no confirmed school-facility outages—small upward pressure only.
7) Wind chill verification: conflicting sources; ≤ -20°F not confirmed by multiple sources, so no automatic-closure move.
8) What would make me wrong? (a) Wind chill actually does reach ≤ -20°F at bus time (many districts close proactively), (b) freezing drizzle coverage is broader than implied and creates widespread glaze on secondary roads, or (c) residual Tuesday conditions refreeze harder than expected, leaving bus routes unsafe despite treatment.

Weighting (per directive): Meteorology (ice timing/QPF) + Safety (bus-route risk) drive the call upward, but History (low closure rates for light-QPF glaze events) and News (no confirmed Wed closures; only activity cancellations) keep it below 40%. Infrastructure data confidence is low but indicates marginal 6:30 AM conditions—favoring delay as the modal outcome. Net: I set full-closure probability at 30% (with a higher, implied chance of a 2-hour delay).

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Wind chill ≤ -20°F is confirmed by NWS/another primary source during 6–8 AM
alternative_scenarios.impact: Closure odds jump sharply (often 70–90%) even with minimal precip due to student bus-stop exposure and operational safety.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Freezing drizzle is patchier than forecast and roads are well-treated by 6:30 AM
alternative_scenarios.impact: School likely open on time; slick spots remain but manageable on primary routes (Brier-risk: overpredicting closure).

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Glaze is more widespread than forecast (more than a trace) and secondary roads remain slick past 7:30 AM
alternative_scenarios.impact: 2-hour delay becomes likely; some districts may close if bus-route test runs fail.

for_schools: Plan for a DELAY-first posture (e.g., 2-hour delay) unless 5–6 AM road checks show widespread glazing on secondary routes or wind chill verification supports ≤ -20°F.
Run pre-dawn bus-route/road checks focused on hills, bridges/overpasses, shaded curves, and stop-heavy neighborhood segments; be ready for targeted route holds if needed.
Salt/sand school entrances, lots, and walkways before 6:00 AM; plan for re-application because very cold pavement reduces salt effectiveness.
If wind chill uncertainty persists, use an objective trigger: confirm NWS wind chill at 6–7 AM and reassess closure if it is ≤ -20°F.
for_residents: Assume black ice 5–8 AM; slow down early, increase following distance, and watch bridges/ramps and subdivision streets.
Students should dress for potentially extreme wind chills and minimize time at bus stops (have a warm indoor wait plan if possible).
Check district communications early (texts/app/website) and allow extra commute time.
for_authorities: Prioritize treatment 4:30–7:30 AM on bridge decks, intersections, hills, and known bus-route trouble spots; consider abrasives where salt is less effective at very low pavement temps.
Coordinate with MDOT/MSP on any lingering crash hotspots from Tuesday and monitor for refreeze-related spinouts before the school commute.
Provide clear public messaging: ‘no new snow’ does not equal ‘safe roads’—thin glaze risk is the main hazard.

positions.rationale: Net meteorological signal for Wed 2026-01-28 in Rockford, MI is: very cold + very light precip with an ice-leaning type. That combination creates an outsized risk of patchy black ice/glaze during early bus/commute hours, but the forecasted liquid amount is small and winds are not strong enough to add widespread blowing-snow or extreme wind-chill closure pressure. Therefore, a delay is more likely than a full closure, and a full snow day remains possible mainly if the freezing drizzle/freezing rain coverage is broader than implied or if roads refreeze hard after Tuesday’s event.
keyFactors: Primary closure hazard is *ice*, not snow: forecast precipitation type is light freezing rain overnight into early morning (roughly 12–6 AM), with temperatures near/just below 0°F, so even tiny QPF (~0.01") can create a thin glaze on untreated roads/sidewalks.
Temperatures stay below freezing all day (high ~14°F), so any glaze/black ice that forms will persist into the AM bus window; no melt-help from sun/temps.
Wind is modest (max ~14 mph). That lowers blowing-snow/whiteout risk on Wednesday and also limits extreme wind chill from the WeatherAPI dataset.

Visibility risk is *nonzero* but looks mostly localized/episodic: near-zero visibility is hinted at a few overnight/late-night hours (freezing fog), which is more likely to cause a delay/extra caution than a full district-wide closure during the school-day window.
No meaningful accumulating snow forecast Wednesday (0 cm). That removes the most common ‘automatic’ snow-day driver for West Michigan districts.
Context from peers: Safety/Infrastructure emphasize a 5–8 AM slickness window and secondary-road/bus-route vulnerability; that nudges probability upward from a purely ‘QPF is tiny’ view.

positions.rationale: From a historical/precedent lens for the Rockford–Kent County area in late January: full closures are most often driven by (a) significant overnight snow that overwhelms morning road clearing, (b) true ice storms with notable glaze, or (c) verified extreme wind chills well below typical thresholds. Wednesday 2026-01-28 looks like a low-snow, light-QPF day, which normally argues against closure. However, the overnight **freezing-rain** type plus very cold pavement temps means even a small amount can produce high-impact slickness on secondary roads/bridges during 5–8 AM—an archetype that produces *some* closures/delays regionally. Given the uncertainty about whether wind chills could briefly reach ~-20°F (conflicting sources), I land at **28%** for a full snow day (with a higher likelihood of a delay than a closure).
keyFactors: **Primary historical trigger here is ICE, not snow.** West Michigan districts usually tolerate cold and small snow amounts, but even a thin glaze of freezing rain/freezing drizzle during the bus window can drive cancellations/disruptions. Forecast shows light freezing rain mainly overnight into ~6 AM with temps near/just below 0°F, so any glaze persists.

**Context matters: Tuesday had advisory-level travel impacts in Kent County.** Even if Wednesday’s QPF is tiny, “leftover + refreeze” mornings are disproportionately closure-prone compared with a clean-slate cold day, because treated main roads can still leave secondary/bus routes slick.

**Cold alone is unlikely to close schools here (historically).** Wind chills look mostly in the single digits below zero per WeatherAPI, which is typically not enough by itself for closure in this region; however, there’s a meaningful *uncertainty* signal from Weather.com showing a potential ~-22°F wind chill that would change the calculus.

**No accumulating snow signal for Wednesday.** With 0 cm forecast and light liquid equivalent, this is not a “plow can’t keep up” closure pattern—more consistent with delay/targeted route adjustments than a full snow day.

positions.rationale:
From a safety/operations standpoint, the profile looks like a classic “thin glaze + bitter cold” morning where **delays are more common than full closures**. The forecast QPF is very small, which argues against a districtwide shutdown, but the timing (pre-dawn) and temperature regime (no melt) elevate risk on secondary roads, lots, and walkways enough that a precautionary decision is plausible if spot icing verifies.

Netting it out: I put **snow day (full closure) at 22%**—non-trivial because ice can be a higher-impact hazard than light snow, but still below 50% because totals are tiny and winds/snow rates aren’t supportive of widespread impassability. A 2-hour delay (or selective bus route adjustments) would be my modal outcome.
keyFactors: Primary hazard is **ice**, not snow: “light freezing rain” is indicated overnight into the early morning, with temps staying well below 32°F all day (high ~14°F, low ~-1°F). Even ~0.01" liquid can create a thin glaze that materially raises crash and slip risk.

**Commute-timed risk window (≈05:00–08:00)** overlaps bus rollout and parent drop-off. That’s the period where small icing amounts have outsized operational impact (braking/turning on neighborhood streets, school lots, sidewalks).

**Persistence of slick spots**: with subfreezing temps all day, any early glaze won’t melt; treatment effectiveness is reduced on very cold pavement, so patchiness can linger, especially on bridges/overpasses and shaded secondary roads.

**Visibility pockets are plausible** (very low vis shown at 00:00 and again near 23:00 with freezing fog). While late-night fog isn’t a school-day driver, it’s a sign of near-surface saturation that can support rime/black ice and complicate early travel.
**No heavy snow loading / no strong wind** on Wednesday (winds ~10–14 mph) lowers the chance of a “full closure” vs a delay or selective route holds.
Contextual risk: **Tuesday had hazardous travel and major crashes regionally** (per news agent). That increases the chance roads are still messy/compacted and refreeze into Wednesday morning.

positions.rationale: As the NEWS specialist, I weight “what decision-makers are reacting to right now” and “what the public safety environment looks like.” The meteorology shows minimal accumulation and light precip, which normally points to school being open. However, Tuesday’s documented crash/closure environment in West Michigan is a meaningful leading indicator: it suggests untreated surfaces and visibility have already been problematic regionally, and with subfreezing temps through Wednesday, any thin glaze from overnight freezing rain can produce disproportionate morning-commute impacts. That combination makes a delay quite plausible and a full closure possible but less likely without confirmed heavier icing or verified extreme wind chills. Net: moderate chance of a snow day-level disruption (closure), with an even higher chance of a delay (not asked, but implied).
keyFactors: High-impact hazard type (ice) despite tiny QPF: forecast indicates light freezing rain overnight into early morning (roughly 12–6 AM), with temps staying below freezing all day—so any glaze persists into bus time.

Strong regional road-safety signal from Tuesday, Jan 27: multiple major crashes and freeway shutdowns reported across West Michigan (including Kent-area M-6) + MSP/MDOT messaging about whiteout/icy conditions. This often correlates with districts choosing a conservative delay/closure the next morning if refreeze occurs.

Worst-timing window aligns with school transportation: safety/infrastructure peers flag 5–8 AM as highest-risk for black ice/patchy slickness; that’s exactly when buses and teen drivers are on the road.

Visibility risk (near-zero pockets) is present in the hourly data (freezing fog/low vis noted late and some overnight hours). While fog alone rarely closes schools, fog + ice raises crash risk and slows response/road treatment effectiveness.

Official district signal is currently absent (as of Tue evening Jan 27): no Rockford Public Schools closure/delay post found yet for Wed Jan 28—this reduces certainty for a full closure, but it does not rule out an early-morning call.

debates.topic: Your risk framing reads ‘high’ overall; meteorologically, the limiting factor is *coverage and amount* of icing (QPF ~0.01"). I agree the *impact-per-drop* is high, but I’d separate ‘high consequence if it occurs’ from ‘likelihood of widespread occurrence’—otherwise we may over-predict full closures versus delays/targeted route holds.
debates.challenge: Your risk framing reads ‘high’ overall; meteorologically, the limiting factor is *coverage and amount* of icing (QPF ~0.01"). I agree the *impact-per-drop* is high, but I’d separate ‘high consequence if it occurs’ from ‘likelihood of widespread occurrence’—otherwise we may over-predict full closures versus delays/targeted route holds.

debates.topic: The historical snow-day rates cited (e.g., ~0.18 for light freezing rain setups) may be reasonable, but I’d want the conditioning to explicitly include ‘QPF ~0.01"’ and ‘precip ends before/near sunrise.’ Many “light freezing rain” events that trigger closures have either higher liquid or occur closer to 6–9 AM; timing matters as much as type.
debates.challenge: The historical snow-day rates cited (e.g., ~0.18 for light freezing rain setups) may be reasonable, but I’d want the conditioning to explicitly include ‘QPF ~0.01"’ and ‘precip ends before/near sunrise.’ Many “light freezing rain” events that trigger closures have either higher liquid or occur closer to 6–9 AM; timing matters as much as type.

If that verifies via an NWS point forecast (or another primary source) during the bus window, closure odds increase materially even without precip. Right now, WeatherAPI winds (generally <10 mph overnight, ~7–12 mph early morning) don’t support -22°F unless temps or winds are lower/higher than shown.
debates.challenge: WEBWEATHERVERIFIER flags a big wind-chill discrepancy (Weather.com showing ~-22°F). Right now, WeatherAPI winds (generally <10 mph overnight, ~7–12 mph early morning) don’t support -22°F unless temps or winds are lower/higher than shown.

I’d like a clearer call on whether the **freezing rain/drizzle is continuous 03:00–06:00 or intermittent**, because continuity is what turns ‘patchy slick’ into ‘widespread glaze.’

debates.topic: Historical closure rates may underweight **ice-at-0°F** scenarios. Districts can run through light snow frequently, but even small icing can flip decisions quickly if it hits the bus window and secondary roads are untreated or refreeze after plowing.
debates.challenge: Historical closure rates may underweight **ice-at-0°F** scenarios. Districts can run through light snow frequently, but even small icing can flip decisions quickly if it hits the bus window and secondary roads are untreated or refreeze after plowing.

That’s reasonable climatologically, but news/road outcomes show that even ‘light’ events are producing major crashes/closures. confidenceJourney.shiftReason: Net meteorological signal for Wed 2026-01-28 in Rockford, MI is: very cold + very light precip with an ice-leaning type. That combination creates an outsized risk of patchy black ice/glaze during early bus/commute hours, but the forecasted liquid amount is small and winds are not strong enough to add widespread blowing-snow or extreme wind-chill closure pressure. Therefore, a delay is more likely than a full closure, and a full snow day remains possible mainly if the freezing drizzle/freezing rain coverage is broader than implied or if roads refreeze hard after Tuesday’s event.

From a historical/precedent lens for the Rockford–Kent County area in late January: full closures are most often driven by (a) significant overnight snow that overwhelms morning road clearing, (b) true ice storms with notable glaze, or (c) verified extreme wind chills well below typical thresholds. Wednesday 2026-01-28 looks like a low-snow, light-QPF day, which normally argues against closure. However, the overnight **freezing-rain** type plus very cold pavement temps means even a small amount can produce high-impact slickness on secondary roads/bridges during 5–8 AM—an archetype that produces *some* closures/delays regionally. Given the uncertainty about whether wind chills could briefly reach ~-20°F (conflicting sources), I land at **28%** for a full snow day (with a higher likelihood of a delay than a closure).

From a safety/operations standpoint, the profile looks like a classic “thin glaze + bitter cold” morning where **delays are more common than full closures**. The forecast QPF is very small, which argues against a districtwide shutdown, but the timing (pre-dawn) and temperature regime (no melt) elevate risk on secondary roads, lots, and walkways enough that a precautionary decision is plausible if spot icing verifies.

Netting it out: I put **snow day (full closure) at 22%**—non-trivial because ice can be a higher-impact hazard than light snow, but still below 50% because totals are tiny and winds/snow rates aren’t supportive of widespread impassability. A 2-hour delay (or selective bus route adjustments) would be my modal outcome.

As the NEWS specialist, I weight “what decision-makers are reacting to right now” and “what the public safety environment looks like.” The meteorology shows minimal accumulation and light precip, which normally points to school being open. However, Tuesday’s documented crash/closure environment in West Michigan is a meaningful leading indicator: it suggests untreated surfaces and visibility have already been problematic regionally, and with subfreezing temps through Wednesday, any thin glaze from overnight freezing rain can produce disproportionate morning-commute impacts. That combination makes a delay quite plausible and a full closure possible but less likely without confirmed heavier icing or verified extreme wind chills. Net: moderate chance of a snow day-level disruption (closure), with an even higher chance of a delay (not asked, but implied).

keyDisagreements.topic: Your risk framing reads ‘high’ overall; meteorologically, the limiting factor is *coverage and amount* of icing (QPF ~0.01"). I agree the *impact-per-drop* is high, but I’d separate ‘high consequence if it occurs’ from ‘likelihood of widespread occurrence’—otherwise we may over-predict full closures versus delays/targeted route holds.
positions: Your risk framing reads ‘high’ overall; meteorologically, the limiting factor is *coverage and amount* of icing (QPF ~0.01"). I agree the *impact-per-drop* is high, but I’d separate ‘high consequence if it occurs’ from ‘likelihood of widespread occurrence’—otherwise we may over-predict full closures versus delays/targeted route holds.

keyDisagreements.topic: The historical snow-day rates cited (e.g., ~0.18 for light freezing rain setups) may be reasonable, but I’d want the conditioning to explicitly include ‘QPF ~0.01"’ and ‘precip ends before/near sunrise.’ Many “light freezing rain” events that trigger closures have either higher liquid or occur closer to 6–9 AM; timing matters as much as type.
positions: The historical snow-day rates cited (e.g., ~0.18 for light freezing rain setups) may be reasonable, but I’d want the conditioning to explicitly include ‘QPF ~0.01"’ and ‘precip ends before/near sunrise.’ Many “light freezing rain” events that trigger closures have either higher liquid or occur closer to 6–9 AM; timing matters as much as type.

keyDisagreements.topic: Tuesday’s crash/whiteout reports are important context, but they can overweight Wednesday’s decision unless we connect them to *overnight refreeze + residual treatment status*. If conditions improve after 7 PM Tue and precip is minimal overnight, past crash density may not translate to Wed closures.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 27 at 9:52AM EST until January 27 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow. Visibilities down to a quarter mile
or less at times. Near white out conditions at times possible.
Additional snow accumulations up to two inches. Winds gusting as
high as 35 mph will cause blowing and
drifting and reduced visibilities.

* WHERE...Barry, Kalamazoo, Kent, Lake, and Newaygo Counties.
Especially along the I 96, I 196 and US 131 Corridors

* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions
may change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow. Plan
on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact
the Tuesday evening commute.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 26 at 3:54PM EST until January 27 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.

* WHERE...A portion of west central Michigan, including the
following county, Newaygo.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Ice jams are notoriously unpredictable. Low-lying areas
along the Muskegon River that are prone to flooding may see
rapidly changing water levels as ice shifts and adjusts.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 350 PM EST, An ice jam was reported by local authorities
on the Muskegon river in southern Newaygo County. The river
gauge at Newaygo shows water levels remaining at minor flood
stage as of Monday afternoon.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. While
flooding associated with freeze up ice jams is typically
minor, conditions can change rapidly and unpredictably.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Newaygo.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement and request they pass this information to the National
Weather Service when you can do so safely.
